proposed changes to the constitution to replace the current system of government
He was replaced as party leader in 1967.
It is not a good idea to miss meals and replace them with snacks.

senses.definition: to change something that is old, damaged, etc. for a similar thing that is newer or better

examples.x: We're thinking of replacing our phone system.
to replace a window/roof
to replace a battery/light bulb
All the old carpets need replacing.
an operation to replace both hips
You'll be expected to replace any broken glasses.
The club does not have the finances resources to replace the damaged equipment.
We will replace a faulty part immediately.

senses.definition: to put something back in the place where it was before

examples.x: I replaced the cup carefully in the saucer.
to replace the handset (= after using the phone).

senses.definition: the act of replacing one thing with another, especially something that is newer or better

examples.x: the replacement of worn car parts

senses.definition: a thing that replaces something, especially because the first thing is old, broken, etc.

examples.x: She had a hip replacement six years ago.
If your passport is stolen you should apply for a replacement immediately.
replacement windows

senses.definition: a person who replaces another person in an organization, especially in their job

examples.x: We need to find a replacement for Sue.

senses.definition: an act of replying to something/somebody in speech, writing or by some action

examples.x: I asked her what her name was but she made no reply.
I received a reply from the firm's managing director.
I got some interesting replies to my post about online banking.
I am writing in reply to your letter of 16 March.
a reply-paid envelope (= on which you do not have to put a stamp because it has already been paid for)
Morocco scored four goals without reply to win the game.

senses.definition: to say or write something as an answer to somebody/something

examples.x: She didn't even bother to reply.
He was quick to reply.
to reply to a question/an email/a query
He hasn't replied to any of my text messages.
She usually replies immediately to comments on her posts.
She simply replied with a smile.
He replied to her question with a scowl.
‘I won't let you down,’ he replied confidently.
The senator replied that he was not in a position to comment.

senses.definition: to do something as a reaction to something that somebody has said or done

examples.x: Italy took an early lead but Brazil replied with two goals in the last five minutes.

senses.definition: a written or spoken account of an event, especially one that is published or broadcast

examples.x: Are these news reports true?
media/press/newspaper reports
And now over to Jim Muir, for a report on the South African election.
A local news station aired a special report on the controversy.
According to this evening's weather report, there will be snow tomorrow.

senses.definition: a spoken or written description of something containing information that somebody needs to have

examples.x: a police report
The company has just released its annual report.
Can you give us a progress report?
You need to compile a report on your findings.

senses.definition: an official document written by a group of people who have examined a particular situation or problem

examples.x: to release/issue a report
The committee will publish its report on the health service next week.
According to the report, we are facing an obesity crisis.

senses.definition: a story or piece of information that may or may not be true

examples.x: There are unconfirmed reports of a shooting in the capital.
I don't believe these reports of UFO sightings.
We are hearing reports that she has quit.
Despite reports claiming the market is heading for a crash, he predicts that prices will rise.

senses.definition: a written statement about a student’s work at school, college, etc.

examples.x: a school report
to get a good/bad report
She got a better report card this time.

senses.definition: an employee whose work is the responsibility of a particular manager

examples.x: a weekly meeting with my direct reports
He was finding one of his reports very difficult to manage.

senses.definition: the sound of an explosion or of a gun being fired

examples.x: a loud report

senses.definition: talked about by people in a bad/good way
to give people information about something that you have heard, seen, done, etc.

examples.x: The crash happened seconds after the pilot reported engine trouble.
The findings are similar to those reported in previous studies.
The company is expected to report record profits this year.
Call me urgently if you have anything to report.
The committee will report on its research next month.
He regularly reports on his activities to his family.
The neighbours reported seeing him leave the building around noon.
Six months later, an inspector reported the problem recurring.
The doctor reported the patient fully recovered.
The house was reported as being in excellent condition.
The house was reported to be in excellent condition.
She was reported by the hospital spokesman to be making excellent progress.
Employers reported that graduates were deficient in writing and problem-solving skills.
She failed to report what had occurred.
‘The cabin's empty,’ he reported.

senses.definition: to present a written or spoken account of an event in a newspaper, on television, etc.

examples.x: The stabbing was widely reported in the press.
Our job is to report the news, not to create it.
The TV news reported that several people had been arrested.
As previously reported, Norfolk police are investigating the case.
It was reported that several people had been arrested.
The media reported me as saying things I did not say.
She reports on royal stories for the BBC.
She has reported from many war zones.
This is Andrew Black reporting for Channel 4 News.

senses.definition: used to show that something has been stated, and you do not know if it is true or not

examples.x: She is reported to earn over $10 million a year.
The president is reported as saying that he needs a break.
Opinion has been reported as fact.
It was reported that changes were being considered.

senses.definition: to tell a person in authority about a crime, an accident, an illness, etc. or about something bad that somebody has done

examples.x: Have you reported the incident to the police?
a decrease in the number of reported cases of AIDS

examples.cf: report somebody to somebody for (doing) something
examples.x: She threatened to report him to the authorities for hunting without a licence.
I’m going to report you if you do that again!
She has reported her daughter missing.

senses.definition: to tell somebody that you have arrived, for example for work or for a meeting with somebody

examples.x: You should report for duty at 9.30 a.m.
Private Smith reporting for duty, sir!
All visitors must report to the reception desk on arrival.
Volunteers have been instructed on where to report.

senses.definition: according to what some people say

examples.x: The band have reportedly decided to split up.

senses.definition: a person who collects and reports news for newspapers, radio or television

examples.x: He leaked the story to a news reporter.
He began his career as a newspaper reporter in New York.
She worked as an investigative reporter for a national newspaper.
a reporter from the  ‘New York Times’

senses.definition: the presenting of and writing about news on television and radio, and in newspapers

examples.x: accurate/balanced/objective reporting
Reporting restrictions on the trial have been lifted (= it can now legally be reported).

senses.definition: to be a member of a group of people and act or speak for them at an event, a meeting, etc.

examples.x: The competition attracted over 500 contestants representing eight different countries.
Local businesses are well represented on the committee (= there are a lot of people from them on the committee).

senses.definition: to act or speak officially for somebody and defend their interests

examples.x: The union represents over 200 000 teachers.

Ms Dale is representing the defendant (= is his/her lawyer) in the case.

senses.definition: to take part in a sports event for a particular country, city, etc.

examples.x: He's been chosen to represent Scotland in next year's World Cup Finals.

senses.definition: to be a symbol of something

examples.x: Each colour on the chart represents a different department.

The artist uses doves to represent peace.

senses.definition: to be something

examples.x: This contract represents 20% of the company's annual revenue.
The final figure represents a 12% increase on the number of new jobs created the previous year.

senses.definition: to be present in something to a particular degree

examples.x: Women and men were represented equally on the teams.

senses.definition: to be an example or expression of something

examples.x: The project represents all that is good in the community.

senses.definition: to show somebody/something, especially in a picture

examples.x: The carvings represent a hunting scene.

The Egyptian goddess is represented as a woman with cow's horns.

senses.definition: to present or describe somebody/something in a particular way, especially when this may not be fair

examples.x: The king is represented as a villain in the play.

The film represents us as helpless victims.

senses.definition: to make a formal statement to somebody in authority to make your opinions known or to protest

examples.x: They represented their concerns to the authorities.
He admitted falsely representing to police officers that the car had been stolen.

senses.definition: the act of presenting somebody/something in a particular way; something that shows or describes something

examples.x: the negative representation of single mothers in the media
The snake swallowing its tail is a representation of infinity.

senses.definition: the fact of having representatives who will speak or vote for you or act in your place

examples.x: The green movement lacks effective representation in Parliament.
The accused was not allowed legal representation.

senses.definition: formal statements made to somebody in authority, especially in order to make your opinions known or to protest

examples.x: We have made representations to the prime minister, but without success.

senses.definition: typical of a particular group of people; that is a typical example of something

examples.x: Is a questionnaire answered by 500 people truly representative of the population as a whole?

senses.definition: containing or including examples of all the different types of people or things in a large group

examples.x: We interviewed a representative sample of teachers.

senses.definition: consisting of people who have been chosen to speak or vote for the rest of a group

examples.x: a representative democracy
the advent of modern representative government

senses.definition: a person who has been chosen to speak or vote for somebody else or for a group of people, or to take the place of somebody else

examples.x: Our elected representatives in government should be doing something about this.

a representative of the UN

senses.definition: a person who works for a company and travels around selling its products

examples.x: a sales representative
She's our representative in France.

senses.definition: a person who is typical of a particular group

examples.x: The singer is regarded as a representative of the youth of her generation.

senses.definition: (in the US) a member of the House of Representatives, the Lower House of Congress; a member of the House of Representatives in the lower house of a state parliament
to make a copy of a picture, piece of text, etc.

examples.x: It is illegal to reproduce these worksheets without permission from the publisher.
The photocopier reproduces colours very well.
This material can be reproduced without payment.
All illustrations are reproduced by kind permission of the Mercury Gallery.

senses.definition: to produce something very similar to something else in a different medium or context; to make something happen again in the same way

examples.x: The atmosphere of the novel is successfully reproduced in the movie.

senses.definition: if people, plants, animals, etc. reproduce or reproduce themselves, they produce young

examples.x: Most reptiles reproduce by laying eggs on land.
cells reproducing themselves (= making new ones)

senses.definition: the act or process of producing babies, young animals or plants

examples.x: sexual reproduction
They are studying reproduction in shellfish.

senses.definition: the act or process of producing copies of a document, book, picture, etc.

examples.x: Use a black pen on white paper to ensure good reproduction.

senses.definition: the quality of recorded sound

examples.x: Digital recording gives excellent sound reproduction.

senses.definition: a thing that has been reproduced, especially a copy of a work of art

examples.x: They have a catalogue with colour reproductions of the paintings for sale.
reproduction furniture (= furniture made as a copy of an earlier style)

senses.definition: a country that is governed by a president and politicians elected by the people and where there is no king or queen

examples.x: newly independent republics
Mary McAleese has been the President of the Republic of Ireland since 1997.

senses.definition: the opinion that people have about what somebody/something is like, based on what has happened in the past

examples.x: to have a good/bad reputation
to build/earn a reputation

senses.definition: the action of asking for something formally and politely; a thing that you formally ask for

examples.x: a request for information

to grant a request
to refuse/decline/reject/deny a request

examples.x: When the software has finished processing the request, a download window pops up.

senses.definition: a song or tune that somebody asks to have played on a radio programme

examples.x: The next request is from a listener in Aberdeen.
a radio request programme

senses.definition: to ask for something or ask somebody to do something in a polite or formal way

examples.x: She requested permission to film at the White House.

senses.definition: to need something; to depend on somebody/something

senses.definition: to make somebody do or have something, especially because it is necessary according to a particular law or set of rules

examples.x: I just require a signature on the form.

senses.definition: something that you need or want

examples.x: the basic requirements of life
a software solution to meet your requirements

senses.definition: something that you must have in order to do something else

examples.x: to meet/fulfil/satisfy the requirements

senses.definition: the act of saving somebody/something from a dangerous or difficult situation; the fact of being saved

a rescue operation/mission
a mountain rescue team
rescue helicopters/boats/workers

senses.definition: an occasion when somebody/something is saved from a dangerous or difficult situation

examples.x: Ten fishermen were saved in a daring sea rescue.

senses.definition: to save somebody/something from a dangerous or harmful situation

examples.x: The coastguard rescued six people from the sinking boat.

senses.definition: a careful study of a subject, especially in order to discover new facts or information about it

to do/conduct/undertake research

a research fellow/assistant/scientist
a research institute/centre/laboratory

senses.definition: to study something carefully and try to discover new facts about it

examples.x: to research a topic/subject

senses.definition: a person who studies something carefully and tries to discover new facts about it

examples.x: European researchers say olive oil could help prevent cancer.

a leading researcher in the field of artificial intelligence
researchers in psychology

senses.definition: to look like or be similar to another person or thing

examples.x: She closely resembles her sister.

senses.definition: an arrangement for a seat on a plane or train, a room in a hotel, etc. to be kept for you

examples.x: I'll call the restaurant and make a reservation.

senses.definition: a feeling of doubt about a plan or an idea

examples.x: I have serious reservations about his ability to do the job.

senses.definition: an area of land in the US that is kept separate for native North Americans to live in
(in India) the policy of keeping a fixed number of jobs or places in schools, colleges, etc. for people who are members of scheduled castes, scheduled tribes or other backward classes
a supply of something that is available to be used in the future or when it is needed

examples.x: cash/foreign currency reserves
large oil and gas reserves
reserve funds

senses.definition: a piece of land that is a protected area for animals, plants, etc.

examples.x: a wildlife/forest reserve

senses.definition: an area of land in the US that is kept separate for native North Americans to live in
the quality that somebody has when they do not talk easily to other people about their ideas, feelings, etc.

examples.x: She found it difficult to make friends because of her natural reserve.

senses.definition: a feeling that you do not want to accept or agree to something, etc. until you are quite sure that it is all right to do so

examples.x: Any contract should be treated with reserve until it has been checked.

senses.definition: an extra player who plays in a team when one of the other players is injured or not available to play
a team that is below the level of the main team
an extra military force, etc. that is not part of a country’s regular forces, but is available to be used when needed

examples.x: the Army Reserve
the reserve police

senses.definition: the lowest price that somebody will accept for something, especially something that is sold at an auction

examples.x: The painting failed to reach to its reserve and was withdrawn from the sale.

senses.definition: available to be used in the future or when needed

examples.x: The money was being kept in reserve for their retirement.

senses.definition: to ask for a seat, table, room, etc. to be available for you or somebody else at a future time

examples.x: I'd like to reserve a table for three for eight o'clock.

senses.definition: to keep something for somebody/something, so that it cannot be used by any other person or for any other reason

examples.x: These seats are reserved for special guests.

senses.definition: to have or keep a particular power

senses.definition: to not decide or make a judgement about something until a later time

examples.x: I'd prefer to reserve judgement until I know all the facts.

senses.definition: to live in a particular place

senses.definition: a house, especially a large or impressive one

senses.definition: the state of living in a particular place

senses.definition: permission to live in a country that is not your own

examples.x: They have been denied residence in this country.

senses.definition: having an official position in a particular place such as a college or university

examples.x: creative writing classes given by the writer in residence

senses.definition: living in a particular place

examples.x: the town’s resident population (= not tourists or visitors)
to be resident abroad/in the UK

senses.definition: a person who lives in a particular place or who has their home there

examples.x: a resident of the United States

senses.definition: a person who is staying in a hotel

examples.x: The hotel restaurant is open to non-residents.

senses.definition: a doctor working in a hospital in the US who is receiving special advanced training
suitable for living in; consisting of houses rather than factories or offices

examples.x: a quiet residential area

senses.definition: requiring a person to live at a particular place; offering living accommodation

examples.x: a residential language course
a residential home for the elderly
residential care for children

senses.definition: a small amount of something that remains at the end of a process

examples.x: pesticide residues in fruit and vegetables

senses.definition: the part of the money, property, etc. of a person who has died that remains after all the debts, gifts, etc. have been paid

senses.definition: the act of giving up your job or position; the occasion when you do this

senses.definition: a letter, for example to your employers, to say that you are giving up your job or position

examples.x: to offer/hand in/tender your resignation

senses.definition: the quality of being willing to accept a difficult or unpleasant situation that you cannot change

examples.x: They accepted their defeat with resignation.

senses.definition: to refuse to accept something and try to stop it from happening

senses.definition: to fight back when attacked; to use force to stop something from happening

senses.definition: to stop yourself from having something you like or doing something you very much want to do

senses.definition: to not be harmed or damaged by something

senses.definition: dislike of or opposition to a plan, an idea, etc.; the act of refusing to obey

senses.definition: the power not to be affected by something

examples.x: AIDS lowers the body's resistance to infection.

senses.definition: a force that stops something moving or makes it move more slowly

examples.x: wind/air resistance (= in the design of planes or cars)

senses.definition: the opposition of a substance or device to the flow of an electrical current
a secret organization that resists the authorities, especially in a country that an enemy has control of

senses.definition: (to choose, etc.) the easiest way of doing something
a definite decision to do or not to do something

examples.x: Have you made any New Year's resolutions (= for example, to give up smoking from 1 January)?

senses.definition: a formal statement of an opinion agreed on by a committee or a council, especially by means of a vote

examples.x: to pass/adopt/approve a resolution

senses.definition: the act of solving or settling a problem, argument, etc.

senses.definition: the quality of being resolute or determined

examples.x: The reforms owe a great deal to the resolution of one man.

senses.definition: the power of a computer screen, printer, etc. to give a clear image, depending on the size of the dots (= marks) that make up the image

examples.x: The graphics look fine, even at low resolution.

senses.definition: to find an acceptable solution to a problem or difficulty

senses.definition: to make a definite decision to do something

examples.x: He resolved not to tell her the truth.

senses.definition: to reach a decision by means of a formal vote

examples.x: It was resolved that the matter be referred to a higher authority.

senses.definition: a place where a lot of people go on holiday

examples.x: seaside/mountain resorts

a popular tourist resort
a popular holiday resort
the resort town of Byron Bay
destination resorts such as Atlantis in the Bahamas

senses.definition: the act of using something, especially something bad or unpleasant, because nothing else is possible

examples.x: There are hopes that the conflict can be resolved without resort to violence.

senses.definition: the first or last course of action that you should or can take in a particular situation

senses.definition: a supply of something that a country, an organization or a person has and can use, especially to increase their wealth

senses.definition: something that can be used to help achieve an aim, especially a book, equipment, etc. that provides information for teachers and students

senses.definition: personal qualities such as courage and imagination that help you deal with difficult situations

senses.definition: a strong feeling of approval of somebody/something because of their good qualities or achievements

senses.definition: a particular aspect or detail of something

senses.definition: about; relating to

senses.definition: in payment for something

senses.definition: to visit somebody or to send a message of good wishes as a sign of respect for them

senses.definition: belonging or relating separately to each of the people or things already mentioned

senses.definition: in the same order as the people or things already mentioned

senses.definition: to improve as a result of a particular kind of treatment

senses.definition: a spoken or written answer

senses.definition: that you can trust and rely on

senses.definition: a period of silence between notes; a sign that shows a rest between notes

examples.x: He wants a big house and an expensive car and all the rest of it.

senses.definition: used to say that the actual amount or number of something is much higher than somebody has stated

senses.definition: not moving

senses.definition: to stop moving

senses.definition: to stop doing something for a while

senses.definition: to stop something by showing it is not true

senses.definition: used when somebody is complaining that they have a lot of work to do
to do or say something to make somebody stop worrying about something
used when you are telling a story to say that you do not need to tell the end of it, because everyone knows it already

senses.definition: to relax and stop worrying

senses.definition: used to show respect when you are talking about somebody who is dead

senses.definition: to feel so satisfied with what you have already achieved that you do not try to do any more

examples.cf: in the rush to do something
examples.x: She was trampled in the rush to get out.
They listened to the rush of the sea below.
The door blew open, letting in a rush of cold air.
He had a rush of blood to the head (= suddenly lost control of himself) and punched the man.
The ancient art is all but lost in the city's headlong rush towards industrialisation.
an adrenaline/a sugar rush

senses.definition: a situation in which you are in a hurry and need to do things quickly

examples.x: What's the rush?
‘I'll let you have the book back tomorrow.’ ‘There's no rush.’
I can't stop—I'm in a rush.
The note looked like it had been written in a rush.

examples.cf: in a rush to do something
examples.x: I’m not in any rush to get back to work.
The trip to Paris was all a mad rush.
a rush job (= one that has been done quickly)

senses.definition: a situation in which people are very busy and there is a lot of activity

examples.x: Book now and avoid the last-minute rush.
The evening rush was just starting.
the Christmas rush
We've had a rush on at the office, dealing with the backlog of orders.

senses.definition: a sudden strong emotion or sign of strong emotion

examples.x: a sudden rush of excitement/fear/anger

senses.definition: a sudden feeling of extreme pleasure or excitement

examples.x: Parachuting will give you the rush of a lifetime.
Users of the drug report experiencing a rush that lasts several minutes.

senses.definition: a sudden large demand for goods, etc.

examples.x: There's been a rush on umbrellas this week.

senses.definition: a tall plant like grass that grows near water. Its long thin stems can be dried and used for making baskets, the seats of chairs, etc.

examples.x: rush matting

senses.definition: the first prints of a film before they have been edited
an occasion when a player or players run towards a player on the other team who has the ball

examples.x: There was a rush on the quarterback.

senses.definition: an occasion when a player runs forward with the ball

examples.x: Johnson carried the ball an average of 6 yards per rush.

senses.definition: the time when parties are held for students who want to join a fraternity or sorority

examples.x: rush week
a rush party

senses.definition: to force somebody/be forced to leave a place quickly

examples.x: He was soon given the bum's rush from the club.

senses.definition: to move or to do something with great speed, often too fast

examples.x: We've got plenty of time; there's no need to rush.
the sound of rushing water
Don't rush off, I haven't finished.
I've been rushing around all day trying to get everything done.
The children rushed out of school.
Firefighters rushed to the scene and extinguished the blaze.
When I fell forwards onto the ice, Michael came rushing to my aid, helping me up giving me an encouraging smile.
His wife immediately rushed to his defence (= defended him against attack or criticism).
Beachgoers rushed to the rescue of three boys as they were pulled out to sea in a rip tide.
My college years seemed to rush past.
She rushed back upstairs.
People rushed to buy shares in the company.
We had to rush our meal.

senses.definition: to transport or send somebody/something somewhere with great speed

examples.x: Ambulances rushed the injured to the hospital.
Relief supplies were rushed in.
He was rushed home immediately.

senses.definition: to do something or to make somebody do something without thinking about it carefully

examples.x: We have to be careful not to rush to judgment.
We don't want to rush into having a baby.
Let us not rush headlong into this crazy project without careful consideration.
Don't rush me. I need time to think about it.

examples.cf: rush somebody into something/into doing something
examples.x: I'm not going to be rushed into anything.

senses.definition: to flow strongly

examples.x: The water rushed in through the hole in the ship's hull.

senses.definition: to try to attack or capture somebody/something suddenly

examples.x: A group of prisoners rushed an officer and managed to break out.
Fans rushed the stage after the concert.

senses.definition: to run into somebody who has the ball
to move forward and gain ground by carrying the ball and not passing it
to give a lot of attention to somebody, especially to a student because you want them to join your fraternity or sorority

examples.x: He is being rushed by Sigma Nu.

senses.definition: to be extremely busy; to have too many things to do

examples.x: Weekdays are slow in the restaurant, but at weekends the staff are rushed off their feet.

senses.definition: people with little experience try to do the difficult or dangerous things that more experienced people would not consider doing
